items.title: B.C. conservation officers call off search for grizzly in Bella Coola attack
items.summary_auto: B.C. conservation officers say they have called off their search for a grizzly bear responsible for a Nov. 20 attack that injured three children and an adult in Bella Coola.

items.title: Japan's viral 7-Eleven egg salad sandwich launches in the U.S. Why is it so popular?
items.summary_auto: 7-Eleven is bringing its famous egg salad sandwich to U.S. stores, announcing Wednesday that its Japanese-style tamago sando has landed, complete with "pillowy milk bread and creamy egg salad made with kewpie mayonnaise." But why is it so popular?

items.title: Canada removes Syria from list of terror-sponsoring states
items.summary_auto: The federal government has removed Syria from its list of states that sponsor terrorism, almost a year after the fall of former president Bashar al-Assad's regime.

items.title: Student magazines are getting axed under Trump’s anti-diversity measures
items.summary_auto: The University of Alabama this week announced the immediate and indefinite closure of two student publications it says run afoul anti-diversity measures imposed by the Donald Trump administration.

items.title: Top court restores conviction of woman who tried to kill mother with insulin injection
items.summary_auto: The Supreme Court of Canada has restored a woman's conviction for attempting to kill her mother by injecting her with insulin.

items.title: Senate unanimously passes bill to eliminate Indian Act's 2nd-generation cut-off
items.summary_auto: The Senate voted unanimously Thursday to advance Bill S-2 with an amendment calling for the removal of the second-generation cut-off from the Indian Act, where children are not eligible for Indian status after two generations of one non-status parent.

items.title: The 'Internet of Animals' has new eyes in space to soon track wildlife from above
items.summary_auto: Bob's Blog: A project designed to track thousands of animals from space, which was halted due to the Russia-Ukraine war, has just returned to space better than ever.

items.title: Is Europe rearming for war with Russia? | About That
items.summary_auto: Investments are being made across Europe to shore up its defence capabilities in the face of increased Russian aggression and an uncertain defence alliance with the United States. Andrew Chang explores the steps Europe is taking to deter a possible Russian attack. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Amid strained ties between India and U.S., Modi and Putin are full of praise for each other
items.summary_auto: A summit between Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Russian President Vladimir Putin that tackled a trade imbalance and pushed to deepen defence ties between the two countries was also steeped in symbolism.

items.title: Avian flu kills dozens of Niverville geese
items.summary_auto: Dozens of Canada geese are dead in Niverville as a result of a confirmed avian flu outbreak.

items.title: Renowned Toronto-born architect Frank Gehry dead at 96
items.summary_auto: Toronto-born architect Frank Gehry, whose works included the 2008 redesign of the Art Gallery of Ontario and the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, has died.

items.title: U.S. Supreme Court to decide whether Trump's birthright citizenship order violates Constitution
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Supreme Court agreed on Friday to take up the constitutionality of President Donald Trump's order on birthright citizenship declaring that children born to parents who are in the United States illegally or temporarily are not American citizens.

items.title: Elon Musk's X slapped with €120M fine by EU regulator for breaching content rules
items.summary_auto: Elon Musk's social media company X was fined 120 million euros ($193.3 million Cdn) by EU tech regulators on Friday for breaching online content rules, the first sanction under landmark legislation that once again drew criticism from the U.S. government.

items.title: Canada proposes keeping Nunavut fishing licences with non-Inuit organization
items.summary_auto: The Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canada (DFO) is looking at reissuing fishing licences off Nunavut's coast to non-Inuit operations, despite a federal court judge saying the initial decision by Ottawa was unreasonable.

items.title: Supreme Court hearings on Quebec secularism law to begin in March
items.summary_auto: Hearings for one of the most highly anticipated Supreme Court of Canada cases in years are scheduled to begin March 23. The outcome of the Supreme Court hearings will likely set major precedents across the country, notably on minority rights and on governments' use of the notwithstanding clause.

items.title: Man, 20, charged in London, Ont., frat party fire that injured sorority sisters during beer Olympics
items.summary_auto: A young man has been charged with criminal negligence causing bodily harm after a fire at a frat party near Western University that injured five sorority sisters, including two seriously, late Tuesday night.

items.title: Mr. Puffs café reportedly used as Laval gang leader's headquarters targeted by gunfire
items.summary_auto: A Mr. Puffs café in Laval, Que., reportedly used as a headquarters by a recently slain gang leader was hit by gunfire overnight.

items.title: RFK Jr.-appointed panel removes universal hepatitis B vaccine recommendations for U.S. infants
FreeStyle Libre 3 sensors to monitor blood glucose recalled following ties to 7 deaths
items.summary_auto: Some FreeStyle Libre 3 plus glucose monitor sensors may provide incorrect low glucose readings, Health Canada says in an alert. The recalled sensors have been linked to injuries and even deaths elsewhere in the world.

items.title: Law society suspends licence of Deepak Paradkar, Ontario lawyer tied to alleged drug lord Ryan Wedding
items.summary_auto: The Law Society of Ontario has suspended the licence of Deepak Paradkar, one of seven Canadians arrested in connection with alleged drug lord Ryan Wedding’s cocaine smuggling ring.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | See final supermoon of 2025
items.summary_auto: Stargazers were treated to a spectacular sight on Thursday evening as a supermoon, the last one of 2025, lit up the night sky.

items.title: IMF says Canada should recommit to debt-to-GDP fiscal anchor
items.summary_auto: A new report by the International Monetary Fund pushes the federal government to recommit to an old fiscal anchor.

items.title: Sask. introduces involuntary treatment legislation as fall sitting ends
items.summary_auto: In its throne speech, the provincial government touted The Compassionate Intervention Act as a key component in its response to the ongoing drug addictions crisis.

items.title: Decades-old study on common weed killer retracted after journal editor says Monsanto may have helped write it
items.summary_auto: An influential research article that claimed a popular weed-killer was safe has been retracted 25 years after it was published, prompting environmental groups in Canada to ask the federal government to review the science on glyphosate use.

items.title: Former Alberta premier Jason Kenney says recall legislation being misused
items.summary_auto: The architect of Alberta's politician recall legislation says it was never meant to be used as a political weapon, but as an "ultimate tool of accountability" if a politician engages in illegal or unethical behaviour.

items.title: Netflix to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery for $72B US
'Oh no, not again': B.C. family sees 4 crashes into backyard in 3 years
items.summary_auto: Kaleden, B.C., resident Brent Burton is asking government to fix a bend in Highway 97, after four vehicles have crashed and ended up in his backyard over three years.

items.title: Canada's unemployment rate fell to 6.5% in November, a steep drop from previous month
items.summary_auto: Canada's economy gained 54,000 jobs in November and the unemployment rate dropped to 6.5 per cent from the previous month's 6.9 per cent rate, Statistics Canada said on Friday.

items.title: Cloudflare investigating early outage that took down LinkedIn, Zoom
items.summary_auto: Internet infrastructure company Cloudflare on Friday said it was investigating an outage that took place in the morning that brought down several global websites, including LinkedIn and Zoom, the second such crash to affect the company in less than three weeks.

items.title: Canada's Summer McIntosh wins 400M freestyle by more than 15 seconds at U.S. Open swim meet
items.summary_auto: Canada's Summer McIntosh set a new U.S. Open record in the women's 400-metre freestyle on Thursday night at the Toyota U.S. Open Championships.

items.title: U.S. Supreme Court paves way for midterm redistricting in Texas in win for Trump, Republicans
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Supreme Court revived on Thursday a redrawn Texas electoral map designed to add more Republicans to the U.S. House of Representatives, boosting President Donald Trump's quest for his party to keep control of Congress in the 2026 midterm elections.

items.title: Worst bird-flu season in years hits Alberta’s poultry farmers
items.summary_auto: A mild fall and long migration is being blamed for increasing numbers of poultry farms coming under orders to contain the spread of highly infectious bird flu. One turkey producer in Alberta is preparing to restart operations after his third such outbreak in four years.

items.title: What happens to the wood from this burnt forest?
items.summary_auto: The cleanup of the Long Lake wildfire in Nova Scotia’s Annapolis County has begun. So what happens to the thousands of hectares of forest that was burned? The CBC’s Aly Thomson went to West Dalhousie to find out.

items.title: Long-awaited electronic medical records system to launch Saturday at IWK Health Centre
items.summary_auto: If all goes according to plan, at 6 a.m. AT on Saturday people working at the IWK Health Centre will become the test case for a generational change to Nova Scotia’s health-care system.

items.title: After she was scammed by a fake holiday market, the real organizers stepped up to help
items.summary_auto: A small business owner in Mount Pearl says she was the victim of a scam, and is warning others ahead of the holidays.

items.title: The Vatican held this Inuvialuit kayak for 100 years. Now it’s coming home
Police find 'I hate my child' search made on couple's device 2 days before boy, 12, died
items.summary_auto: The first-degree murder trial of Brandy Cooney and Becky Hamber in Milton, Ont., heard texts in which the women questioned whether a boy in their care might be dying a month before his death in December 2022.

items.title: Merrily We Roll Along was Sondheim's biggest failure. Now it's a feature film triumph
items.summary_auto: Stephen Sondheim's 1981 musical Merrily We Roll Along was an abysmal failure that closed almost as soon as it opened. Now a Tony-winning revival has it headed to potential box-office success.
